Posts.Content: Hi, I know this is about 15 days late, but I don't get to read the message board often. Hope you are doing better. Don't really know if I can help with being scared, but I had stage 3 Breast Cancer in May of 2006. Surgeon performed a radical single mastectomy. I had chemotherapy, but refused radiation. I am very glad of that decision on radiation, because the left tip of the lung would have been damaged which can lead to other complications later. That was just my personal decision & by no means should be yours. I am only telling you my experience & personal decisions. October 2006 I saw a Naturepathic Dr. in Charlotte, NC and have been doing great ever since. I changed my diet, NO SUGAR - Sweets, pasta, white bread of any kind. Drink 8 oz of a Green Drink which consists of juiced green vegetables. If you want the recipe I can give it to you. I take supplements specifically for Cancer remission. My Oncologists semi agrees with me, but they don't have time to read the studies on all of this Chemo and radiation and the side effects, which in my opinion kill your body. I feel better than ever before. You may eat sugar once in awhile, but in moderation. Moderation is the key. I no longer have the headaches, which were daily. Every moment counts, the Lord has given me a second chance at life. Taking care of your body is very important with Cancer. This is the best thing that has happened to me. I have been blessed by this disease and am living better than ever. If you need to talk, feel free to contact me. I have checked the box to receive an email when someone responds to this message. Take care and I will be praying for you. Beverly    On 12/15/2007 lookingforward wrote: Hi everyone! I had a single mastectomy about two weeks ago. They thought it was stage 1 but I had two tumors, one was about 1 cm and the other was 3.5 cm. MUCH larger than expected. ER/PR +, Her2 -, and unfortunately two lymph nodes positive, K67 tests were 3 and 8???. PET scan and MRI negative for lymph and other areas, but I am really depressed. Doctors were telling me that chemo was a big maybe and now I am stage 2B and they are talking chemo, radiation and not so encouraging about my chances for survival. I am freaking out. I don't mind the treatment (had a port put in yesterday) but I want some hope to hang my hat on! Everything keeps changing for the worst and I don't trust anything anymore. Please give me some advice. I am meeting with my oncologist on Tuesday and can't stop crying.  Best wishes to all.
Posts.Title: SO Scared!

Posts.Title: SO Scared!

Posts.Content: Hi Grac234,   I would suggest you find a "good honest" ND, (Naturepath Doctor), one that has a college degree in Naturepathic Medicine. There are a lot of imposters out there who don't know what their doing just to make money off of your illness. I see one in Charlotte, NC. He has my own regimen of diet & supplements. You could call him & ask about a referral in your location. His name is Dr. William Pearce, 704-225-3382 or consult CTCA for one. Combined medicine is becoming popular. I have been under the care of an ND for about a year for my stage 3 Breast Cancer and am doing absolutely wonderful. I also do follow up tests & examines with my oncologist. I have to avoid sugar, which keeps cancer cells growing. This includes pasta, breads...etc.  My supplements for Cancer keep it in remission. This doctor has a track record of patients being 10-20 years out, whereas traditional meds alone are 2-4 yrs. out. I figured what have I got to lose!! It wasn't easy making this decision, but am glad I did. I have lots info. on my illness & how far I have come in a year, but there's not room for all of it. I am a miracle, took chemo, 8 treatments,  but refused radiation. Have not regretted the decision either. Feel free to contact me. Hope everything turns out well for you.  Take care of yourself, would love to hear from you Beverly, (Tumor)
Posts.Title: alternative treatment to aromatase inhibitors

Posts.Content: On 1/20/2008 Cajun wrote: Surgery was done this past Monday to remove a milk duct from my right breast.  Diagnosed this past Thursday with Stage 0 'in-situ" duct carcinoma.  My symptoms were pain and a dark bloody discharge. Doctor wants to do a lumpectomy and then 5-6 weeks of radiation.  No lymph nodes will be removed and no chemo. will be given.   Since a digital mammogram done in December 2007 showed nothing an MRI was done on both breasts this past Thursday.  I am awaiting the results that may show something in both breasts.  The doctor has said that I can delay treatment because this is a slow growing cancer. I beleive that cancer is a fungus.  I am familiar with Doug Kaufman.  I plan to follw the Phase One for a least 30 days to help kill off as much fungus as possible but I am not sure that it is a good idea to not have the lumpectomy and radiation. Does anyone know if I consult or get a second opinion with the Cancer Treatment Center will I be obligated to receive treatment from them?  The closest location is Oklahoma but that is 1300 miles round trip. Is there a directory available for doctors that beleive that cancer is a fungus and will prescribe anti-fungal drugs? Does anyone know if Dr. David Holland still sees patients? Thanks for your help.     I have never heard of cancer being a fungal disease. But, I can tell you I had BC in the spring of 2006 and my last mammogram was done in 2004 and nothing showed up. I found my tumor on my own and it was in the ductal glands in the breast that never gave me any problems. My Cancer was, (stage 3) with (3 lymph nodes), affected. Had a single mastectomy.  So, you never know about this cancer. I have heard MRI is a good way to be tested. I had also gotten a CT of my liver in 2005 and no trace of cancer showed on those results. I took chemo. Refused radiation. Have seen too many people suffer permanent damage from radiation. The Radiologist told me I would have lung damage, but only the tip. Have also been told it would damage my heart and that can lead to congestive heart failure. I didn't take the chance and don't regret my decision. I won't let any Doctor burn up my organs. I have changed my diet and take cancer supplements and am doing great!!! I will be interested in how things turn out for you. Only you can decide what is best for your treatment.  Take Care, Beverly
Posts.Title: In-situ duct cells

Posts.Content: I googled "Breast Cancer Camisole", found a host of websites. Hope this helps. Take care. Beverly  On 1/7/2008 roofrat63 wrote: Hi this is Susan. Its the 7th now and past her surgery date. i pray all went well. Joining support groups with other BC women really helped me and to this day I still do 2 groups. In our group we have a women getting ready for a double mastectomy. I too would love to know the brand of the cammy you got your friend. warm regards Susan
Posts.Title: breast cancer camisole

Posts.Content: On 1/12/2008 mesa4 wrote: My friend was diagnosed inJan 2007 with breast cancer and had chemo and radiation (34 rad treatments).  Her treatment ended in Dec 2007.  Her throat is bothering her and she is wondering if this is a after-effect from radiation and what are the side/after effects of radiation?  Thank you! I am sorry to hear about your friend and hope she recovers.  In 2006 I had breast cancer. I refused radiation because of the permanent damage it would cause. To this day I don't regret my decision. I have turned to alternative medicine. Cancer Treatment Centers of America work with a licensed Naturopath in their treatment of cancer.  I see a Naturopath in Charlotte, NC and have been in remission for almost 2 yrs.  Chemotherapy is what I took. Had 8 treatments but will not do that again either.  I feel better than ever because of the cancer supplements and diet change. Some hospitals are integrated alternative medicine into their treatment plans, but it is a slow process. Hopefully, insurance companies will recognize that some of this treatment is much more effective and less costly than traditional medicine alone.  Hope this info. helps.
Posts.Title: pain in the throat - after-effects of radiation

Posts.Content: Hi Debbie,   Your brave to take all that treatment, my hat off to you! I rejected radiation therapy for my stage 3 Breast Cancer and am glad I did and even more glad since reading your posting. My Oncologist & Radiologist told me I would have damage to the tip of my lung only, didn't tell me about the heart, but had heard stories of heart damage. I sought out a good ND, (Homeopathic Doctor), in Charlotte, NC and he said there was no way the radiation would bypass my heart. I am on a good cancer diet with supplements and am doing very well. Blood tests are good and feel better than ever before.  God Bless you and take care
Posts.Title: Hero's

Posts.Content: Hi, It is very unfortunate that your neighbor shared with you information that was not to be given out. I agree you should pray for your neighbor who has cancer and also pray for the neighbor who told you. She broke confidentiality and if the one who has cancer finds out she may not ever trust her again. With all that said, it is obvious from appearance sake something is wrong with your neighbor. I had the same surgery almost 2 yrs. ago and wore hats. Hope your neighbor eventually shares with you, but until she does, just pray for her. God Bless you, Bev
Posts.Title: She doesn't know I know...what to do??I want to say something...

Posts.Content: Hi, I too am almost 2 years out and still have pain and tightness in my left arm. Had a radical mastectomy with 19 lymph nodes removed on June 2, 2006. My surgeon told me I would have the discomfort and some numbness, this is natural from the surgery and nerves affected.  Hope this helps ease your concerns. Have never heard of the cord, but in a way it feels like there is a cord inside when I use that arm to reach for something. My Prayers are with you. Bev
Posts.Title: Pain 10 months after having lymph nodes removed

Posts.Content: On 1/19/2004 Mary Pat D. wrote: I have recently completed treatment for breast cancer that involved a lumpectomy, chemo and radiation. I am now on Arimidex for follow up treatment. My question to my doctor is...shouldn't I have a CT Scan to be certain the cancer is truly gone? Since it did spread to my lymph nodes, I cannot help but feel the need to know that it no longer exists in my body. Someone, other than my oncologist, told me I should have a CT scan just to be certain the cancer is gone. I feel the need for closure here, so I too would like a CT scan. However, my oncologist does not feel it is necessary. Has anyone else experienced this situation or have any advice for me in pursuing this matter further? Thanks... Mary Pat Hi Mary Pat,  Yes, I believe you should have a CT Scan follow-up, providing your insurance will pay for it. I had BC in the Spring of 2006 and last year I had two mammograms and 1 ultra sound. It depends on your doctor, but I have a good dr. who listens to me and if I want a scan done she will approve it, no matter what it takes. This is your disease and your body, not theirs. Let us know what takes place. Take Care, Beverly
Posts.Title: CT Scans - Necessary or Not

Posts.Title: CT Scans - Necessary or Not

Posts.Content: Hi Kay, I am concerned for you. My stomach turned when I was reading your posting. I would get to a good Doctor ASAP!  Mammogram, Ultra Sound whatever it takes. It may not be anything, but I wouldn't take any chances. I am a Beast Cancer Survivor, almost 2 yrs. and any signs of cancer, lumps, discharge etc. etc. I have it checked out. This is not worth letting go, even if it is not Cancer. Please let us know what happens. Beverly (Tumor)
Posts.Title: Nipple Discharge and Itchy....
